rows.text: Medieval with later repairs; two pointed arches. Grade II* listed, Scheduled Ancient Monument.
Single segmental arch. Carries public bridleway.
Three bridges, "probably late 18th-century" or "late 17th-century". Grade II listed. The three bridges carry a public byway.
1820, single segmental arch. Grade II listed. Carries a public byway.
Probably late 18th-century; single span. Grade II listed. Carries public byway.
Probably early 19th-century; three stone arches, one larger and two small. Grade II listed.
Late 17th-century; single-span. Grade II listed. Carries public footpath.
Probably late 17th- or 18th-century; described as "ruinous" in 1725. Single-span. Grade II listed. Carries public bridleway.
Single-span. Scheduled Ancient Monument. Carries public bridleway.
Probably 17th-century, widened in 1734. Grade II listed. Carries public road.
Probably 18th-century, but maybe earlier. Grade II listed. Carries public byway.
Possibly 17th-century; single segmental arch. Grade II listed.
17th-century; two clapper slabs and a single arch. Grade II* listed. Carries public footpath.
Probably 17th- or 18th-century; single-span. Grade II listed.
17th- or 18th-century; single-span. Grade II listed. Alongside public road.
Single arch. On Open Access land.
Early- or mid-18th-century; single span. Grade II listed. Carries public bridleway.
Probably 18th-century; single span. Grade II listed. Carries public footpath.
Probably 17th-century; single segmental arch. Grade II listed. Adjacent to ford.
Probably 18th-century; single span. Grade II listed.
18th-century; single span. Grade II listed. Carries public bridleway.
Probably 17th- or 18th-century; single span. Also known as High Wath Bridge, Mattie Benn's Bridge, Hannah Benn Bridge and Roman Bridge. :46 Grade II listed.
1729 with 20th-century parapet; single span. Grade II listed.
18th-century; three low arches, with integral walled sheep pen on southern bank. Grade II* listed, Scheduled Ancient Monument.
1664; five segmental arches. Grade I listed, Scheduled Ancient Monument. Carries public bridleway.
18th-century; single span. Grade II listed. Carries public footpath.
Moved to current position in 1968 from Goyt's Bridge hamlet. In open access land.
Probably 18th-century; single-span. Grade II listed. Carries public footpath.
Single semicircular arch. :114–115 Carries public bridleway.
Early 18th-century; single-span. Grade II listed, "A rare example of a perfectly preserved packhorse bridge." Carries public byway.
17th-century or earlier; single pointed arch. Formerly Grade II listed, now delisted. On private land.
18th-century, single segmental arch. Grade II listed. Carries public bridleway.
Mid-18th-century; three segmental arches. Grade II listed. Carries public bridleway.
Probably 17th- or 18th-century; single round arch. Grade II listed.
18th- or 19th-century; single-span. Grade II listed, Scheduled Ancient Monument.
Probably 18th- or early 19th-century. Grade II listed. Carries public footpath.
Scheduled Ancient Monument. Carries public bridleway.
Probably medieval. Grade II listed; two pointed arches. Carries footpath alongside ford on public road.
Probably 18th-century; single semicircular arch. Grade II listed. Carries public footpath.
Probably medieval, with 19th- and 20th-century alterations. Grade II listed. Carries public bridleway.
16th- or 17th-century alterations; three pointed arches. Grade II listed. Carries public bridleway.
17th-century; single cambered arch. Grade II listed. Carries public bridleway.
Probably 17th-century; 3 segmental arches. Grade II listed. Alongside ford on public road.
1699 per datestone (contra English Heritage listing, which says "Mid C18"); single segmental arch. Grade II listed.
Late 17th- or early 18th-century; single segmental arch. Grade II listed.
Possibly early 18th-century; single wide segmental arch. Grade II listed. On private land.
17th-century; single round arch. :56 Grade II listed.
Probably 18th-century; single round arch. Grade II listed.
c.1750; seven brick arches. Under restoration.
Possibly 16th-century in origin, rebuilt 18th century; two semicircular arches. Grade II listed. Carries public bridleway.
Also known as Roman Arch. Probably late medieval or 16th-/17th-century; two arches. Grade II listed. Carries public footpath.
18th-century; single segmental span. Grade II listed. Carries public bridleway.
Late 18th-century; five semicircular arches with cutwaters. Grade II listed.
"Medieval". Adjacent to Oldham & Ripponden Trust Turnpike bridge (1864) and Brownhill Bridge Mill, which is Grade II listed.
17th-century, two round arches. Grade II listed.
16th/17th-century, parapets added 1814–15; single span. Grade II* listed, Scheduled Ancient Monument.
Single-span. Listed per Hinchliffe, :61 but not in English Heritage listings.
"Perhaps C17"; single semicircular arch. Grade II listed.
Date uncertain; single semi-elliptical arch. Grade II listed.
17th-century or perhaps earlier; two segmental arches. Grade II* listed, Scheduled Ancient Monument. Carries a public footpath.
Probably 17th-century; two round arches. Grade II listed. Carries public bridleway.
Also known as the Roman Bridge. Probably 15th-century; eleven small arches (eight on bridge, three on causeway). Grade II* listed, Scheduled Ancient Monument.
Possibly 13th-century; four arches. Scheduled Ancient Monument.

Three similar bridges between Thurcaston and Cropston: Sandham Bridge () and Coffin Bridge (), both with two arches, and a third, single-span, bridge at . All three are 16th- or 17th-century and separately Grade II listed.
14th-century; double chamfered cambered arch. Grade II* listed'
15th-century; three segmental arches. Grade II* listed, Scheduled Ancient Monument.
Original date unknown, probably reconstructed late 19th century; four small arches. Grade II listed' In grounds of Walsingham Abbey.
Probably 15th-century; two pointed arches. Grade II listed, Scheduled Ancient Monument. Carries roadside pavement.
18th-century per English Heritage (Hinchliffe says 1698 :65); two segmental arches. Grade II listed.
Possibly 16th- or 17th-century; three segmental pointed arches. Grade II listed. Carries public footpath.
Also known as Haxby Bridge. 1822; single-span. Grade II listed. Carries public right-of-way.
Probably 18th-century; single segmental arch. Carries public footpath.
Possibly 15th-century; two segmental arches on differing alignments. Grade II listed. Carries public bridleway.
1619; single segmental arch. Grade II* listed. Carries public footpath.
Probably 17th-century; single small semicircular arch. Grade II listed.
Late 16th-century; single semicircular arch. Grade II* listed.
17th- or 18th-century; single slightly pointed arch. Grade II listed.
Late 17th- or early 18th-century; single shallow arch with additional flood arch. Grade II listed. Carries public byway alongside ford.
Probably early 17th-century; single segmental arch. Grade II listed. Carries public byway.
Probably early 19th-century; single segmental arch. Grade II listed. Adjacent to public road.
18th-century; single segmental arch. Grade II listed. Carries farm access.
16th-century, repaired 1621; single segmental arch. Grade II listed. Carries public footpath.
Probably 17th-century; single arch. Grade II listed. Carries public footpath.
Also known as World's End Bridge. 1672; single segmental arch. Grade II listed. Carries public footpath.
17th- or early 18th-century; single round arch. Grade II listed.
Fall or Padside or Darley Beck
Single segmental span. Scheduled Ancient Monument.
13th-century, restored 1874; single round span. Scheduled Ancient Monument. Carries public footpath.
Probably early 18th-century; single segmental arch. Grade II listed.

Late 18th- or early 19th-century; single semicircular brick arch. Grade II listed. Although described as such in the official listing, this canal bridge is not a packhorse bridge by most accepted definitions.
17th-century; single segmental arch. Grade II listed. Carries public bridleway.
Medieval; two segmental-headed arches. Grade II* listed, Scheduled Ancient Monument. Adjoins public road through ford.
Possibly 15th-century; single-span. Grade I listed, Scheduled Ancient Monument.
17th- or 18th-century; single low segmental arch. Grade II listed.
Early 18th-century; two segmental arches. Grade II listed, Scheduled Ancient Monument. Carries public byway.
17th- or 18th-century rebuild of medieval bridge; four round arches (two inserted 1994–97 for flood relief purposes). Grade II listed. Carries public footpath alongside road.
Possibly 15th-century; two round arches. Grade I listed, Scheduled Ancient Monument. Carries public bridleway.
17th-century; three semicircular arches. Grade II listed, Scheduled Ancient Monument. Carries public bridleway.
Late medieval; single-span. Grade II* listed, Scheduled Ancient Monument. Carries public bridleway.
Late medieval; single-span. Grade II* listed, Scheduled Ancient Monument. Carries public footpath.
17th–18th-century; two rounded arches. Grade II listed. Carries public road.
Three semicircular arches. Grade II listed. Carries public footpath.
Three semicircular arches. Grade II listed. Carries public footpath.
Probably late medieval; two segmental arches. Grade II listed. Carries public footpath.
Late medieval; two round arches. Grade II listed. Carries public footpath.
17th- or 18th-century, possibly earlier. Grade II listed.
Medieval, restored 1952; two semicircular arches. Grade II listed. Carries public footpath, just upstream of 19th-century road bridge (also called Vicarage Bridge).
Medieval, restored 1952; single semicircular arch. Grade II listed.
Probably 16th-century; fourteen round arches. Described as "perhaps the least altered old bridge in the county" Scheduled Ancient Monument. Carries public bridleway.
Probably 16th-century; single segmental brick arch. Grade II listed. Adjacent to public road.
ca. 1446 with 18th-century alterations; four pointed arches. Grade II* listed, Scheduled Ancient Monument. Carries public footpath.
18th-century; single semicircular brick arch. Grade II listed.
18th-century; three semicircular arches. Grade II listed.
15th-century; three stone and two brick arches. Grade II* listed, Scheduled Ancient Monument.
c.1723; single-span. Grade II listed. Carries public footpath.
Probably 18th-century; single-span. Grade II listed. Carries public right-of-way.
Possibly 17th-century; single segmental arch. Grade II listed. Carries public footpath.
Date uncertain; single-span. Grade II listed. Carries public footpath.
Also known as Hepton Brig. :93 c.1510; three segmental arches. Grade II* listed. Carries public right-of-way.
17th- or 18th-century; single-span. Grade II* listed. Carries public footpath.
Early 18th-century. Grade II listed, "a rare survival of a pack-horse bridge sited within a suburban setting".
Date uncertain; single steeply arched span. Grade II listed. Carries public footpath.
Probably early 17th-century; single-span. Scheduled Ancient Monument. On Access Land.
Date uncertain; single-span. Grade II listed. Carries public footpath.
Probably 18th-century; three elliptical arches. Grade II listed.
Probably early 18th-century; single-span. Grade II listed. Carries public bridleway.
Medieval, widened in 19th century; three low two-centred arches. Grade II listed. Carries public footpath.
1725; four segmental arches. Grade II listed. Carries public footpath.
Late 18th- or early 19th-century, possibly earlier, single arch. Grade II listed. Carries public bridleway.
17th-century or earlier, two round arches. Grade II listed. Adjacent to ford on public road.
